reviewText: The plot story seem simple...Former Devil's Hole Gang leaders Kid Curry and Hannibal Heyes (alias Joshua Smith and Thaddeus Jones), a pair of successful and popular outlaws trying to go straight after a lifetime of mostly non-violent banditry.This Butch Cassidy clone, which was an ABC movie of the week like the Night Stalker was, was a cute western plot..which became a series. It had thatMaverick: The Complete First Seasontype feel to it.Now in the 1970's , the idea of DVDs and Blue ray players and watching whole series at home was a concept unheard of. These TV shows were not thought of for hi-dep TV in the 1970's, when this show original aired. However these masters recordings seem to be the best uncut versions of these shows. Better than the cut up versions that are run on cable television todayThe pilot (one disk one of season one) has a special addition to it. It has an audio commentary track with show producer/creator Glen Larson. It will also give you insights on this show that you heard before. I only wish that Davis or Murphy, who are still alive, or a few of the guest cast could have done a commentary track on an episode. Alas that did not happenBen Murphy (Jones) was in the whole show's run. Pete Duel started as Smith, until his  untimely death in the middle of show's second season. Instead of canceling this western comedy, Duek was replaced by actor Roger (Dark Shadows) Davis, who did the show's original openning narration credits. With Murphy and Davis in the lead, they tried to make the show seamless after Duel's death. Think Bewitched and the multiple Darrens.The guest stars were actors from the universal stable of 1970's actors including Susan St James, Sally Fields, William Ruseel, James Drury and many more. Familar faces make this show filled with great acting talent.Lets be honest, This was a fluffy popcorn show. It was a show for western adventure, fun and laughs. You will enjoy this show is you just sit back and watchIt is good to watch a show that you do not have follow week to week. You can watch any episode and do not have to watch a multiple story arc, as you do todayIt is worth just watching for the fun.Bennet PomerantzAUDIOWORLD

reviewText: This just don't make good shows like this anymore. I love the humor and the time that it was set in. It goes back to a time when life was a lot simpler. The actors did a wonderful job with the series, but did hate that Pete Duel's ended so soon.

reviewText: I fell in love with the tragic Pete Duel all over again.  The stories hold up; it's a classic Western -- a bit of "Maverick," a bit of "Butch Cassidy," and a lot of great chemistry between the lead actors.  As good as the chemistry between Newman and Redford in "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid."Duel didn't believe it when Will Geer told him he could be as big a star as Newman, but he was right.  There wasn't a dang thing that Newman had in "Butch" that Duel didn't have in this show.  They could have killed off Ben Murphy and the show could have continued.  But without Pete, it lost its heart.For an interesting story, look into how Pete died -- especially the lies his girlfriend told to the police afterward.  Goes to show depression, alcohol and guns don't mix.  The guy who gave him the gun should wake up screaming every night.  But that's just my opinion.  Everyone on the set knew he drank and drank hard.  Oh, well.  It's a thousand times too late now....

reviewText: Pete Duel,Ben Murphy,and Roger Davis did such a good job in this comedy western. Sally Field did a wonderful job guest starring as their friend Clementine Hale. It was so well done she brought the character back a second time. Other fine guest stars were Jessica Walters, Edd Byrnes, Lee Majors and many more.

reviewText: I was very young when the show aired, so being able to see it again was wonderful. The quality of the DVDs was great. Maybe some people got a bad batch. I didn't enjoy the show as much when Rodger Davis took over Peter Duel's part. With no disrespect to Rodger Davis, when Peter Duel died the show died too. Peter was defiantly the star of the show.
summary: Alias Smith & Jones: The Complete  Series  Review

reviewText: I'm a little surprised to see other people have rated the video quality on the complete series to be good. I've watched the first 5 episodes and find the video quality to be horrible. Most DVDs I watch on my upconverting blu-ray player look pretty good, or at least acceptable. These episodes look grainy. It looks like they are doing a weird frame rate. When people talk, there lips appear to be blurring. Almost like a ghosting effect. I noticed the same thing on a dark train sequence where the wood appeared to be blurring (Episode 5, The girl in Boxcar #3). I've never had an issue with anything else, so I completely believe its the DVD mastering. I notice the mps is low compared to other full frame DVDs of series I own. That said, this is a great series which I used to watch years ago and always enjoyed. 5 stars for great show, 1 star for the video quality.
